To start, we can combine the sum in the denominator by multiplying the numerator and denominator of the fraction $\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}+1}$ by the conjugate of the denominator.
The conjugate of $\sqrt{3}+1$ is $\sqrt{3}-1,$ so we have \[\frac{1}{1+ \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}+1}} = \frac{1}{1+\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}+1}} \cdot \frac{\sqrt{3}-1}{\sqrt{3}-1} = \frac{1 \cdot (\sqrt{3}-1)}{1 \cdot (\sqrt{3}+1) + \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}+1} \cdot (\sqrt{3}-1)}.\]The denominator of the fraction is
\begin{align*}
1 \cdot (\sqrt{3}+1) + \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}+1} \cdot (\sqrt{3}-1) &= (\sqrt{3}+1) + \frac{1 \cdot (\sqrt{3}-1)}{\sqrt{3}+1} \\
&= (\sqrt{3}+1) + \frac{\sqrt{3}-1}{\sqrt{3}+1} \\
&= (\sqrt{3}+1) + \frac{\sqrt{3}-1}{\sqrt{3}+1} \cdot \frac{\sqrt{3}-1}{\sqrt{3}-1} \\
&= (\sqrt{3}+1) + \frac{3-2\sqrt{3}+1}{1^{2}-(\sqrt{3})^{2}} \\
&= (\sqrt{3}+1) + \frac{4-2\sqrt{3}}{1-3} \\
&= (\sqrt{3}+1) + \frac{2- \sqrt{3}}{-2} \\
&= (\sqrt{3}+1) - \frac{2- \sqrt{3}}{2}.
\end{align*}Since $\frac{2-\sqrt3}{2}=\frac{2}{2}-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}=1-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2},$ this is equal to \[(\sqrt{3}+1) - \left( 1-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \right) = \sqrt{3}+1-1 + \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} = \boxed{\frac{1 + 3\sqrt{3}}{2}}.\]
